  <td width="94%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:94.48%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;text-transform:uppercase;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;text-transform:none;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:5.52%;">
  <p align="right" style="font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;text-transform:uppercase;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;text-transform:none;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="94%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:94.48%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;text-transform:uppercase;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;text-transform:none;"><a href="a06-9742_110k.htm#ExhibitIndex_101644">EXHIBIT INDEX</a><a name="ExhibitIndex_100918"></a></font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:5.52%;">
  <p align="right" style="font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;text-transform:uppercase;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h1 align="center" style="margin:12.0pt 0in 3.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">CAUTIONARY NOTE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING
STATEMENTS</font></b><a name="CautionaryNoteRegardingForwardloo_100922"></a></h1>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Statements in this Annual Report on Form 10-K
of MAIR Holdings, Inc. (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;) under the caption &#147;Business&#148;
and &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&#148; and elsewhere in this report are forward-looking and are based upon
information currently available to the Company.&#160;
The Company, through its officers, directors or employees, may also from
time to time make oral forward-looking statements.&#160; In connection with the &#147;safe harbor&#148;
provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, the Company
is hereby identifying important factors that could cause actual results to
differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statement made by
or on behalf of the Company.&#160; Many
important factors that could cause such a difference, including those
surrounding Mesaba Aviation, Inc.&#146;s bankruptcy proceedings, are described in &#147;Item
1A.&#160; Risk Factors&#148; in this Annual Report
on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Undue reliance should not be placed on the
Company&#146;s forward-looking statements because the matters they describe are
subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other unpredictable
factors, many of which are beyond the Company&#146;s control.&#160; The Company&#146;s forward-looking statements are
based on the information currently available and speak only as of the date on
which this report was filed with the United States Securities and Exchange
Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;).&#160; Over time, actual
results, performance or achievements will likely differ from the anticipated
results, performance or achievements that are expressed or implied by the
Company&#146;s forward-looking statements, and such differences might be significant
and materially adverse to the Company&#146;s shareholders.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All subsequent written or oral
forward-looking statements attributable to the Company or persons acting on the
Company&#146;s behalf are expressly qualified by the factors described above.&#160; The Company assumes no obligation, and disclaims
any obligation, to update information contained in this Annual Report on Form
10-K, including forward-looking statements, as a result of facts, events or
circumstances after the date of this report, except as required by law in the
normal course of its public disclosure practices.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='1',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h1 align="center" style="margin:12.0pt 0in 3.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART I</font></b><a name="PartI_100925"></a></h1>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 style="font-style:italic;margin:12.0pt 0in 3.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Item
1.&#160; BUSINESS</font></i></b><a name="Item1_Business_100926"></a></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">MAIR Holdings, Inc. (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;)
is the holding company for Mesaba Aviation, Inc., a regional air carrier based
in Minneapolis, Minnesota (&#147;Mesaba&#148;) and Big Sky Transportation Co., a regional
air carrier based in Billings, Montana (&#147;Big Sky&#148;).&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky are each wholly-owned
subsidiaries of Holdings.&#160; The financial
position and results of operations of Mesaba were deconsolidated from the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements effective October 13, 2005, the
date Mesaba filed for bankruptcy protection.&#160;
Mesaba and Big Sky are the Company&#146;s reportable segments that are
managed independently.&#160; Additional detail
on segment reporting is included in &#147;Item 8.&#160;
Financial Statements and Supplemental Data, Note 13 &#151; Segment
Information&#148; in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mesaba</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba
Bankruptcy</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October 13, 2005 (the &#147;Petition Date&#148;),
Mesaba voluntarily filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District
of Minnesota (the &#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;) for bankruptcy protection under Chapter
11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.&#160;
Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy filing was a direct result of events leading up to
and following the bankruptcy filing by Northwest Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Northwest&#148;)
on September 14, 2005.&#160; Northwest is
Mesaba&#146;s major customer, and as a result of Northwest&#146;s missed payments to
Mesaba before and after Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy filing, Mesaba estimates that
Northwest owes Mesaba approximately $29.1 million as of March 31, 2006 under
the various agreements between the parties, net of amounts that Mesaba owed to
Northwest under these agreements.&#160;
Northwest has also proposed and made several significant fleet changes
that have resulted in Mesaba operating a substantially reduced fleet.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest&#146;s missed payments to Mesaba and
Northwest&#146;s actions regarding its fleet and schedule changes adversely affected
Mesaba, and Mesaba determined that it could not sustain its operations outside
of court protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; Since the Petition Date, Mesaba has
continued, and will continue, to operate its business as a debtor-in-possession
under the jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy Court and in accordance with the
applicable provisions of the Bankruptcy Code, the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy
Procedure and applicable court orders.&#160;
In general, as a debtor-in-possession, Mesaba is authorized under
Chapter 11 to continue to operate as an ongoing business, but may not engage in
transactions outside the ordinary course of business without the prior approval
of the Bankruptcy Court.&#160; All of Mesaba&#146;s
vendors are being paid for all goods furnished and services provided to Mesaba
after the Petition Date in the ordinary course of business.&#160; However, under Section 362 of the Bankruptcy
Code, actions to collect most of Mesaba&#146;s prepetition liabilities are
automatically stayed.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba intends to utilize the Chapter 11
process to reorganize its business and emerge as a competitive and profitable
supplier of regional flights.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s
major goals to be realized through the Chapter 11 process include:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">restructuring
its costs to realize savings, including both labor and non-labor contracts
related to its operations;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#147;right-sizing&#148;
its workforce and overhead to account for Mesaba&#146;s reduced fleet; and</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">affirming
Mesaba&#146;s relationship with Northwest.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba has taken many actions to achieve
these goals, several of which are discussed in more detail below.&#160; Mesaba must ultimately confirm a plan of
reorganization to successfully emerge from bankruptcy.&#160; Mesaba will continue to refine its Chapter 11
goals as it deems necessary to respond to changing conditions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As provided by the Bankruptcy Code, on
November 2, 2005, the United States Trustee for the District of Minnesota
appointed an Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors (the &#147;Creditors&#146;
Committee&#148;). The Creditors&#146; Committee and its legal representatives have a
right to be heard on all matters that come before the Bankruptcy Court
concerning Mesaba&#146;s reorganization. There can be no assurance that the
Creditors&#146; Committee will support Mesaba&#146;s positions or plan of reorganization.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under Section 365 of the Bankruptcy Code,
Mesaba may assume, assume and assign, or reject certain executory contracts and
unexpired leases, including leases of real property, subject to the approval of
the Bankruptcy Court and certain other conditions.&#160; In general, if Mesaba rejects an executory
contract or unexpired lease, it is treated as a prepetition breach of the lease
or contract in question and, subject to certain exceptions, relieves Mesaba of
performing any future obligations.&#160;
However, such a rejection entitles the lessor or contract counterparty
to a prepetition general unsecured claim for damages caused by such deemed
breach and, accordingly, the counterparty may file a claim against Mesaba for
such damages.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s original Section
365 deadline related to real estate leases was December 12, 2005.&#160; On June 6, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court
extended the Section 365 deadline to the earlier of confirmation of a
reorganization plan or December 10, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba&#146;s rights relative to certain leases,
particularly aircraft and aircraft-related leases, are governed by Section 1110
of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; Section 1110
provides a 60 day deadline from the date of filing for bankruptcy by which,
absent agreement with the other party or authorization by the Bankruptcy Court,
Mesaba must take action with respect to such lease, after which the applicable
lessor&#146;s, sublessor&#146;s, secured party&#146;s or vendor&#146;s right to take possession of
the relevant equipment and to enforce its rights is not limited or affected by
the automatic stay provision of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; Northwest and Mesaba initially agreed to
extend the deadline with respect to aircraft Mesaba leases or subleases from
Northwest.&#160; Although that agreement
expired as of February 15, 2006, Mesaba continues to use the aircraft in
accordance with Northwest&#146;s scheduling requests and is performing under the
subleases for all aircraft that have not been idled at Northwest&#146;s
request.&#160; Because the aircraft currently
operated by Mesaba are subleased from Northwest, Mesaba&#146;s decisions with
respect to such aircraft will be timed with Northwest&#146;s fleet plan decisions
made during Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba&#146;s estimate of its liability for
prepetition general unsecured claims is reflected in Mesaba&#146;s &#147;liabilities
subject to compromise.&#148;&#160; Mesaba&#146;s deconsolidated
balance sheet at March 31, 2006 includes $60.0 million in liabilities subject
to compromise.&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Financial
Statements and Supplemental Data, Note 20 &#151; Financial Information of Mesaba&#148;
for additional information.&#160; Mesaba
expects its liabilities subject to compromise to change in the future as a
result of future negotiations with creditors or damage claims created by Mesaba&#146;s
rejection of various aircraft leases, executory contracts and unexpired
leases.&#160; Generally, if Mesaba assumes an
aircraft financing agreement, executory contract or unexpired lease, Mesaba is
required to provide for a cure for existing defaults under such contract or
lease as a condition to such assumption.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Section 1113 of the Bankruptcy Code provides
that a debtor may reject its collective bargaining agreements (&#147;CBAs&#148;) if the
debtor first satisfies various statutory requirements and obtains the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s approval of such rejection.&#160;
Mesaba commenced Section 1113 proceedings with all four of its unions,
and on January 31, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved Mesaba&#146;s tentative
agreement reached with the Transport Workers&#146; Union (&#147;TWU&#148;).&#160; The Bankruptcy Court heard testimony from </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba and the remaining three unions for
Mesaba&#146;s pilots, mechanics and flight attendants in February and March
2006.&#160; On May 18, 2006, the Bankruptcy
Court denied Mesaba&#146;s motion to reject.&#160;
Although the Bankruptcy Court agreed with Mesaba&#146;s core business
assumptions, the court ruled that Mesaba failed to satisfy certain technical
elements required to authorize rejection of the labor contracts under Section
1113.&#160; The Bankruptcy Court stated that
if Mesaba chooses to remedy the defects in its original motion, the court would
hear a renewed motion in a prompt manner.&#160;
On June 12, 2006, Mesaba filed a renewed motion for authority to reject
its CBAs, and the Bankruptcy Court began hearing the motion on June 26,
2006.&#160; There can be no assurance that
Mesaba will ultimately obtain the labor cost savings it requires to
successfully reorganize.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to Mesaba&#146;s request for
debtor-in-possession financing, in October 2005, Holdings provided a commitment
letter and term sheet to Mesaba for such financing.&#160; At Mesaba&#146;s request, Holdings extended the
deadline for the expiration of the commitment letter two times.&#160; On March 24, 2006, the commitment
expired.&#160; Mesaba is seeking
debtor-in-possession financing from other sources, but there can be no
assurance that Mesaba will be able to obtain such financing on acceptable
terms.&#160; If Mesaba is unable to obtain
debtor-in-possession financing by the end of the second quarter of fiscal 2007,
Mesaba may not have sufficient cash to continue to fund its operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To successfully emerge from Chapter 11, the
Bankruptcy Court must confirm a plan of reorganization, the filing of which
will depend on the timing and outcome of numerous ongoing matters in the
Chapter 11 process, potentially including the outcome of Northwest&#146;s Chapter 11
case.&#160; The reorganization plan will be
subject to a vote by certain classes of creditors, including Mesaba&#146;s secured
creditors and unsecured creditors.&#160; The
Bankruptcy Court will generally not approve a reorganization plan unless all
impaired classes of creditors vote to accept the plan; however, Mesaba may
elect to invoke certain provisions of the Bankruptcy Code in order to obtain
confirmation of the plan over the vote of a dissenting class of creditors.&#160; In addition to the voting requirements for
confirmation, Mesaba will have to satisfy other provisions of the Bankruptcy
Code in order to confirm its reorganization plan, including showing that the
plan is feasible.&#160; Additionally, the
absolute priority rule in the Bankruptcy Code requires that all of the debtor&#146;s
creditors must be paid in full; otherwise the equity holders in the debtor are
not entitled to retain their equity interests, unless certain exceptions to the
absolute priority rule are met.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba had the exclusive right for 120 days
from the Petition Date to file a plan of reorganization, followed by 60 days in
which to obtain acceptance of the plan.&#160;
On March 9, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved a motion filed by Mesaba
to extend the deadline for Mesaba&#146;s exclusive right to file such a plan to
August 10, 2006.&#160; Mesaba intends to file
a plan of reorganization as soon as it is able, but there can be no assurance
that a reorganization plan will be proposed by Mesaba within the required time
frame or that any additional extensions Mesaba may request will be approved.&#160; Additionally, there can be no assurance that
the Bankruptcy Court will confirm any plan of reorganization proposed by Mesaba
or that any such plan will be implemented successfully.&#160; The reorganization plan will determine the
rights and claims of various creditors and security holders.&#160; At this time, it is not possible to predict
accurately the effect of the Chapter 11 reorganization process on Mesaba&#146;s
business, nor can Mesaba make any predictions concerning how the various
creditor claims and interests of security holders will be determined in the
bankruptcy proceedings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba
Operations</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba operates as a regional air carrier
providing scheduled passenger service as &#147;Mesaba Airlines/Northwest Airlink&#148;
and &#147;Mesaba Airlines/Northwest Jet Airlink&#148; for Northwest.&#160; As discussed above, both Northwest and Mesaba
filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on September 14, 2005 and October
13, 2005, respectively.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s
relationship with Northwest is governed by the Airline Services Agreement (the &#147;ASA&#148;)
dated August 29, 2005.&#160; Prior to the ASA,
Mesaba provided regional airline services to Northwest pursuant to two separate
agreements, an Airline Services Agreement (the </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#147;Airlink Agreement&#148;) that governed Mesaba&#146;s
operation of Saab 340 jet-prop aircraft (&#147;Saabs&#148;), and a Regional Jet Services
Agreement (the &#147;Jet Agreement&#148;) that governed Mesaba&#146;s operation of Avro RJ85
regional jets (&#147;Avros&#148;).&#160; The ASA is a
ten-year omnibus agreement that incorporates the existing payment terms for the
Saabs and Avros contained in the Airlink Agreement and the Jet Agreement, and
adds new payment terms for the Canadair regional jets (&#147;CRJs&#148;) that Mesaba
began operating in October 2005.&#160; As of
March 31, 2006, Mesaba served 102 cities in the United States and Canada from
Northwest&#146;s hub airports located in Minneapolis/St. Paul, Detroit and Memphis.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest purchases Mesaba&#146;s entire capacity
and pays Mesaba in arrears on the 11</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">th</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> and 26</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">th</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> of each month for regional airline services that
Mesaba provides to Northwest utilizing the Saabs and Avros.&#160; Beginning in October 2005, Northwest began
paying Mesaba, on a regular bi-monthly basis, on the 1</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">st</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> and 16</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">th</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> of each month for regional
airline services that Mesaba provides to Northwest utilizing the CRJs.&#160; The CRJ payment made on the 1</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">st</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> of each month represents a
prepayment based on an estimate of regional airline services to be provided by
Mesaba for the first 15 days of the month.&#160;
The CRJ payment made on the 16</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">th</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> of the month consists of a prepayment based
on an estimate of regional airline services to be provided by Mesaba for the 16</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">th</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> through the end of the
month, as well as a true-up amount adjusting for actual services provided by
Mesaba in the prior month.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For flights utilizing the Saabs, Mesaba
recognizes revenue for each completed available seat mile, or &#147;ASM&#148; (the number
of seats in an aircraft multiplied by the number of miles those seats are
flown), and purchases fuel which is set at a fixed price of $0.835 per gallon,
ground handling and other services from Northwest.&#160; Mesaba paid Northwest $18.3 million, $21.9
million and $19.7 million for ground handling and other services fiscal 2006,
2005 and 2004, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For flights utilizing the Avros, Mesaba
recognizes revenue for each block hour flown (the elapsed time between aircraft
departing and arriving at a gate).&#160;
Northwest provides fuel and airport and passenger related services at
Northwest&#146;s expense for the Avros.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For flights utilizing the CRJs, Mesaba
recognizes revenue through monthly expense reimbursement payments for actual
expenses incurred relating to aircraft rent, maintenance, landing fees and fuel
(which is set at a fixed price of $0.70 per gallon for the CRJs); semi-monthly
payments for each block hour and cycle operated; a monthly fixed cost payment
based on the size of the CRJ fleet (intended to cover Mesaba&#146;s costs that are
not reimbursed through the monthly reimbursement payments, which consist mainly
of labor costs, ground handling costs, overhead and depreciation) and margin
payments based on the revenues described above calculated to achieve a target
operating margin.&#160; The target operating
margin through April 2007 is set at a fixed amount, after which time the target
operating margin will be based on the average operating margin of the publicly
traded United States domestic regional airlines operating primarily regional
jet aircraft, excluding Pinnacle Airlines Corp. (&#147;Pinnacle&#148;), and any regional
carrier under bankruptcy protection, subject to a margin cap and floor.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The ASA contains termination provisions that
allow both Mesaba and Northwest to terminate the ASA in the event the other
party breaches the agreement, subject to the other party&#146;s right to cure the
breach within a prescribed time period.&#160;
Additionally, Northwest may terminate the ASA in the event of certain
lease and other performance defaults by Mesaba; failure by Mesaba to maintain
required insurance coverage; failure by Mesaba to allow inspections pursuant to
the ASA; change in control events; revocation or failure by Mesaba to obtain
Department of Transportation (&#147;DOT&#148;) certification; if Mesaba or its affiliates
operate an aircraft type that causes Northwest to be in violation of its
collective bargaining agreement with its pilots; failure to elect a chief
executive officer/president of Holdings or Mesaba reasonably acceptable to
Northwest; if a specified percentage of the aircraft subject to the agreement
are not operated for a specified period of time, other than as a result of the
Federal Aviation Administration (the &#147;FAA&#148;) grounding all aircraft for all
carriers; if there is a strike, cessation or interruption of work </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">involving Mesaba pilots, flight attendants or
mechanics providing service; or if Holdings breaches its agreement entered into
with Northwest concurrently with the ASA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the ASA, all scheduled flights that
Mesaba operates are designated as Northwest flights using Northwest&#146;s
designator code in all computer reservation systems with an asterisk and a
footnote indicating that Mesaba is the carrier providing the service.&#160; In addition, flight schedules of Mesaba and
Northwest are closely coordinated to facilitate interline connections, and
Mesaba&#146;s passenger gate facilities at the Minneapolis/St. Paul International
Airport, Detroit Metropolitan Airport and Memphis International Airport are
integrated with Northwest&#146;s facilities in the main terminal buildings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba, through the ASA, receives ticketing
and certain check-in, baggage, freight and aircraft handling services from
Northwest at certain airports.&#160; In
addition, Mesaba receives its computerized reservations services from
Northwest.&#160; Northwest also performs all
marketing, scheduling, yield management and pricing services for Mesaba&#146;s
flights.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The ASA provides for incentive payments from
Northwest to Mesaba based on achievement of certain operational goals on a
semi-annual basis.&#160; Such incentives
totaled $3.7 million, $3.1 million and $4.6 million in fiscal 2006, 2005 and
2004, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Approximately $25.7 million, net of reserve,
or 79.2% and $25.9 million, or 88.8%, of Mesaba&#146;s March 31, 2006 and 2005
accounts receivable balances were due from Northwest and were not
collateralized.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Upon execution of the ASA, and pursuant to a
separate agreement between Holdings and Northwest, Holdings issued to Northwest
an amended and restated warrant (the &#147;Warrant&#148;) to replace the warrants held by
Northwest to reduce the number of shares of Holdings&#146; common stock issuable upon
exercise from 4,151,922 shares exercisable at prices ranging from $7.25 to
$21.25 per share to an aggregate of 4,112,500 shares exercisable at a price of
$8.74 per share.&#160; The Warrant expires ten
years from the date of the ASA.&#160; The
Warrant will become exercisable for sixty percent of the shares upon the
delivery by Northwest of the 15<sup>th</sup> CRJ aircraft to Mesaba and an
additional 4% of the shares with each subsequent delivery of each of the next
ten CRJ aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To date, Northwest has delivered only two CRJ
aircraft to Mesaba.&#160; Northwest has
advised Mesaba that it will remove one of the CRJs that Mesaba currently
operates and place the CRJ with Northwest&#146;s newly formed subsidiary, Compass
Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Compass&#148;).&#160; As part of
its reorganization, Northwest has also requested bids from regional airlines
for the operation of up to 126 CRJ aircraft, 124 of which are currently
operated by Pinnacle and two of which are operated by Mesaba.&#160; Mesaba has submitted a proposal to conduct
all CRJ flying for Northwest.&#160; If Mesaba
is not awarded some or all of the CRJ business, Northwest will remove the other
CRJ that Mesaba currently operates.&#160; If
Mesaba is awarded additional CRJs by Northwest, it is possible that the terms
of the Warrant may be renegotiated to reflect any new arrangement between the
parties.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Holdings also entered into a registration
rights agreement to cover the registration of the shares of stock currently
held by Northwest and the shares of stock that could be issued to Northwest
upon exercise of the Warrant.&#160; To date,
the Company has not filed this registration statement, and it is unlikely that
one will be filed unless and until the exact nature of the relationship between
Mesaba and Northwest is determined via each company&#146;s respective bankruptcy proceedings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In connection with the ASA, Mesaba incurred
all of the start-up costs necessary to bring the CRJ fleet into service.&#160; For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2006,
Mesaba incurred and expensed approximately $7.0 million in start-up costs
related to adding the CRJ aircraft into its fleet, and Holdings incurred and
expensed approximately $0.3 million in related start-up costs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Finally, in connection with the ASA, and
pursuant to its separate agreement with Northwest, Holdings made a capital
contribution of approximately $31.7 million to Mesaba in September 2005, just
prior to Northwest filing for bankruptcy.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky operates as a regional air carrier
based in Billings, Montana, providing scheduled passenger, freight, express
package and charter services.&#160; As of
March 31, 2006, Big Sky provided scheduled air service to 22 communities in
Montana, Colorado, Idaho, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming.&#160; Big Sky operates daily scheduled flights
providing interline and online connecting services and local market
services.&#160; Big Sky also has code-sharing
agreements with Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, America West Airlines, US Air and
Northwest, where its services are marketed jointly with those air carriers for
connecting flights.&#160; Big Sky began
service to Pocatello, Idaho and Walla Walla, Washington in the fourth quarter
of fiscal 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky participates in the Essential Air
Service (&#147;EAS&#148;) program with the DOT.&#160;
The EAS program subsidizes air carriers to provide air service to
designated rural communities throughout the country that could not otherwise
economically justify that service based on their passenger traffic.&#160; The DOT pays EAS subsidies for each departure
in a covered market.&#160; Big Sky was recently
reselected as the EAS provider for seven Montana cities for a two-year period
beginning March 1, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky purchased fuel from Northwest for
$1.4 million, $1.7 million and $1.9 million in fiscal 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Regulations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to Federal aviation laws, the DOT
and the FAA have certain regulatory authority over the operations of all air
carriers.&#160; The jurisdiction of the FAA
extends primarily to the safety and operational provisions of the Federal
Aviation Act, while the responsibility of the DOT involves principally the
regulation of certain economic aspects of airline operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">FAA
Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba and Big Sky each hold an air carrier
certificate issued by the FAA permitting Mesaba and Big Sky to conduct flight
operations in compliance with Federal Aviation Regulations, which are the same
regulatory requirements applicable to major airlines.&#160; The FAA regulations to which Mesaba and Big
Sky are subject are extensive and include, among other items, regulation of
aircraft maintenance and operations, equipment, ground facilities, dispatch,
communications, training, weather observation, flight personnel and other
matters affecting air safety.&#160; To ensure
compliance with its regulations, the FAA requires airlines to obtain operating,
airworthiness and other certificates that are subject to suspension or
revocation for cause.&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky
hold all certificates necessary for their operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under FAA regulations, Mesaba and Big Sky
have established, and the FAA has approved, maintenance programs for all
aircraft they operate.&#160; These programs
provide for the ongoing maintenance of Mesaba&#146;s and Big Sky&#146;s aircraft, ranging
from frequent routine inspections to major overhauls.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s and Big Sky&#146;s aircraft require
various levels of maintenance or &#147;checks&#148; and periodically undergo complete
overhauls.&#160; Maintenance programs are
monitored closely by the FAA, with FAA representatives routinely present at the
airline&#146;s maintenance facilities.&#160; The
FAA issues Airworthiness Directives (&#147;ADs&#148;), which mandate changes to an air
carrier&#146;s maintenance program.&#160; These
ADs, which include requirements for structural modifications to certain
aircraft, are issued to ensure that the nation&#146;s transport aircraft fleet
remains airworthy.&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky
are currently, and expect to remain, in compliance with all applicable
requirements under all ADs and FAA approved maintenance programs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">DOT
Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba and Big Sky each hold a Certificate of
Public Convenience and Necessity issued by the DOT under federal aviation
laws.&#160; As certificated carriers, Mesaba
and Big Sky are required to file quarterly reports with the DOT, including a
report of aircraft operating expenses and related statistics.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Transportation
Security Administration Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In response to the terrorist attacks of
September 11, 2001, Congress enacted the Aviation and Transportation Security
Act of 2001 (the &#147;ATSA&#148;).&#160; The ATSA
created the Transportation Security Administration (the &#147;TSA&#148;) to oversee
aviation and airport security.&#160; Among
other security measures, the ATSA enhanced background checks, provided for
federal air marshals aboard flights, improved flight deck security, enhanced
airline crew security training, improved training of security screening
personnel and enhanced airport perimeter access.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Emergency
Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April 2003, Congress enacted the Emergency
Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act (the &#147;Wartime Act&#148;), which included,
among other items, a $2.3 billion grant to United States airlines for security
fees previously remitted to the TSA and $100 million for reimbursement of
aircraft cockpit door reinforcement costs.&#160;
In connection with reimbursements under the Wartime Act, for the year
ended March 31, 2004, Mesaba recognized $2.3 million as &#147;other nonoperating
income,&#148; and Big Sky recognized $0.3 million as &#147;other nonoperating income&#148; and
$0.2 million as a reduction of &#147;administrative and other expense&#148; in the
accompanying consolidated statements of operations.&#160; Expenditure of these funds requires
compliance with the provisions of the Wartime Act.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Railway
Labor Act</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba&#146;s and Big Sky&#146;s relations with its
labor unions are governed by the Railway Labor Act (the &#147;RLA&#148;).&#160; Comprehensive provisions are set forth in the
RLA establishing the right of airline employees to organize and bargain
collectively and imposing a duty upon air carriers and their employees to exert
every reasonable effort to make and maintain collective bargaining
agreements.&#160; The RLA contains detailed
procedures which must be exhausted before a lawful work stoppage may occur,
including a formal declaration of an impasse by the National Mediation Board.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Environmental Regulations</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba and Big Sky are subject to regulation
under various environmental laws and regulations, including the Clean Air Act,
the Clean Water Act and Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and
Liability Act of 1980.&#160; In addition, many
state and local governments have adopted environmental laws and regulations to
which Mesaba&#146;s and Big Sky&#146;s operations are subject.&#160; Environmental laws and regulations are
administered by numerous federal and state agencies.&#160; Management of Mesaba and Big Sky believe that
they are in compliance with standards for aircraft exhaust emissions and fuel
storage facilities issued by the Environmental Protection Agency.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other
Regulations</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the Noise Control Act of 1972 and the
Aviation Safety and Noise Abatement Act of 1979, the FAA has authority to monitor
and regulate aircraft engine noise.&#160;
Management of Mesaba and Big Sky believe that their aircraft comply with
or are exempt from such regulations.&#160; As
a foreign carrier operating in Canada, Mesaba is subject to regulation by
Canada&#146;s Transport Canada department and has been issued a Foreign Air Carrier
Operating Certificate and Canadian Transportation Agency economic license.&#160; Because Northwest maintains certain contracts
with the Department of Defense, Mesaba is subject to that department&#146;s periodic
inspections.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Insurance</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company carries the types of insurance
customary in the airline industry, including coverage for public liability,
passenger liability, property damage, aircraft loss or damage, baggage and
cargo liability, war risk, directors&#146; and officers&#146; and workers&#146;
compensation.&#160; Mesaba, through the ASA,
purchases aviation liability, war risk and hull coverage through a combined
placement with Northwest.&#160; The ASA
requires that Mesaba maintain specified levels of insurance coverages and also
obligates Northwest to use commercially reasonable efforts to allow Mesaba to
continue to participate in Northwest&#146;s insurance plan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Both Mesaba and Big Sky were given the option
under the ATSA to purchase certain third-party war risk liability insurance
from the United States government on an interim basis at rates that are more
favorable than those available from the private market.&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky have purchased this
insurance from the FAA as provided under the ATSA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is highly competitive as
a result of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 (the &#147;Deregulation Act&#148;),
which generally increased competition by eliminating restrictions on fares and
route selection.&#160; The Deregulation Act
also contributed to the withdrawal of national and major carriers from
short-haul markets by allowing them to more easily obtain additional long-haul
routes, which can be more efficiently and profitably served by larger jet
aircraft.&#160; Elimination of barriers to
entry into new markets, however, also created greater potential for competing
service by other carriers operating small, fuel-efficient aircraft on
short-haul routes serving small and medium-sized cities.&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky compete with other
regional airlines on most routes they serve.&#160;
Mesaba and Big Sky also face competition from regional carriers offering
service to alternative hubs for connecting flights.&#160; Other carriers, including major carriers, can
at any time institute competing service on routes served by Mesaba or Big Sky.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The ASA does not prohibit Northwest from
contracting with other regional airlines to provide the same services that
Mesaba currently provides.&#160; Northwest
currently has an airline services agreement with Pinnacle, and Pinnacle serves
many of the same cities as Mesaba.&#160;
Northwest could choose to expand its agreement with Pinnacle in
competition with Mesaba.&#160; Northwest could
also choose to establish relationships with other regional airlines.&#160; Finally, Northwest has formed a new
subsidiary, Compass, and Northwest intends to use this subsidiary to operate
regional flights.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competitive factors in the airline industry
generally include fares, frequency and dependability of service, convenience of
flight schedules, type of aircraft flown, airports served, relationships with
travel agents, and efficiency and reliability of reservations systems and
ticketing services.&#160; The compatibility of
flight schedules with those of other airlines and the ability to offer through
fares and convenient inter-airline flight connections are also important
competitive factors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Fuel</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company believes that the following
arrangements assure an adequate supply of fuel for current and future
operations for both Mesaba and Big Sky, provided that Northwest does not
experience a supply shortage.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mesaba</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba has arrangements with Northwest for
its fuel requirements.&#160; Certain
provisions of the ASA protect Mesaba from fluctuations in aviation fuel prices
for Saab and CRJ flights.&#160; The ASA also
requires Northwest to provide fuel for the Avros, at Northwest&#146;s expense, to
Mesaba.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">9</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky purchases its fuel under arrangements
with several fuel suppliers.&#160; None of
these arrangements provides protection from fluctuations in fuel prices and
supply.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Fares</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mesaba</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba derives its passenger revenue by
selling its capacity to Northwest at predetermined rates.&#160; Under the ASA, Mesaba is primarily paid by
Northwest per available seat mile or per completed block hour, depending on the
type of aircraft operated.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky generates its passenger revenues from
passenger ticket sales through participation in Airline Reporting Corp., a
clearinghouse for travel agencies, its own reservations center in Billings, a
ticket by mail program and on-line e-ticketing.&#160;
Big Sky has ticketing and baggage agreements with all major airlines
that serve its region, which allow its services to be sold by those airlines.&#160; Big Sky establishes its passenger fares on a
market-by-market basis utilizing a combination of factors, including the cost
of providing the service based upon projected passenger levels, the competitive
price of alternative means of transportation (including both air and surface)
and the distance between markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Aircraft
Maintenance</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The maintenance performed on Mesaba&#146;s and Big
Sky&#146;s aircraft can be divided into two general categories:&#160; routine line maintenance and major
overhauls.&#160; Line maintenance consists of
routine daily and weekly scheduled maintenance checks on aircraft, including
pre-flight, daily, weekly and overnight checks and any diagnostic and routine
repairs.&#160; Mesaba and Big Sky employ their
own aircraft, avionics and engine maintenance staffs that perform substantially
all routine line maintenance to the aircraft and engines.&#160; Mesaba contracts out most of its major
overhauls on airframes, engines and other rotable parts on the aircraft at FAA
authorized facilities.&#160; Major overhauls
on Big Sky&#146;s fleets, including airframes, engines and other rotable parts, are
performed internally or at FAA authorized facilities.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Airport
and Terminal Services</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba&#146;s ticket counter and baggage-handling
space is leased from local airport authorities or other airlines at all of the
airports served.&#160; In certain of the
cities it serves, Mesaba receives support services under agreements with
Northwest.&#160; In accordance with the ASA,
for flights utilizing Saabs, Mesaba pays local airport authorities for the use
of the landing fields at rates that are based on the number of flights per day,
fixed fees or on the number of aircraft landings and aircraft weight.&#160; Northwest pays for Mesaba&#146;s landing fees for
flights utilizing Avros.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba receives other revenue from Northwest,
Pinnacle and other airlines for ground handling services performed at the
Minneapolis/St. Paul, Detroit and other spoke airports.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky leases airport counter, baggage and
ramp space for ground services and customer services at all of the cities it
currently serves.&#160; Big Sky contracts for
ground handling services from other airlines as needed.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">10</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-9742-1\task1193764\9742-1-ba-01.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Jun 27 14:35 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Employees</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2006, Holdings had five
employees, and its subsidiaries employed 3,779 employees with approximately 41%
of those employees represented by labor unions.&#160;
Mesaba had 3,535 (1,128 part-time) employees, and Big Sky had 244 (58
part-time) employees.&#160; Neither Mesaba nor
Big Sky had any official work stoppages during fiscal 2006.&#160; The Company&#146;s labor agreements are as
follows:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mesaba</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.3%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="21%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:21.18%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Dispatchers</font></p>
  </td>

  <p align="right" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3,535</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:1.3%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:48.52%;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:1.32%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:12.28%;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.3%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

</table>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As discussed above in &#147;Mesaba Bankruptcy,&#148;
Mesaba sought approval from the Bankruptcy Court to reject all of its CBAs and
impose new contract terms on its labor unions.&#160;
On January 31, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court approved Mesaba&#146;s tentative
agreement reached with the TWU.&#160; The
Bankruptcy Court heard testimony from Mesaba and the remaining three unions for
Mesaba&#146;s pilots, mechanics and flight attendants in February and March
2006.&#160; On May 18, 2006, the Bankruptcy
Court denied Mesaba&#146;s motion to reject.&#160;
Although the Bankruptcy Court agreed with Mesaba&#146;s core business
assumptions, the court ruled that Mesaba failed to satisfy certain technical
elements required to authorize rejection of the labor contracts.&#160; The Bankruptcy Court stated that if Mesaba
chooses to remedy the defects in its original motion, the court would hear a
renewed motion in a prompt manner.&#160; On
June 12, 2006, Mesaba filed a renewed motion for authority to reject its CBAs,
and the Bankruptcy Court began hearing the motion on June 26, 2006.&#160; Mesaba is continuing to negotiate with its
unions and remains committed to reaching consensual agreements.&#160; However, there can be no assurance that
Mesaba will be able to do so.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
